52385.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
The word 'māratta' is an abstract noun derived from the noun 'māra' by adding the taddhita suffix '-tta'. It signifies the state or condition of being Māra. In the contextual sentence, 'mārattaṃ kareyya' refers to performing the role or embodying the state of Māra, alongside Sakka and Brahmā, emphasizing a position of ultimate spiritual or worldly authority that is deemed impossible for a woman to attain.
52385.sutta_1: ‘aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ itthī sakkattaṃ kareyya … mārattaṃ kareyya … brahmattaṃ kareyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
52385.example_1: They understand: ‘It’s impossible for a woman to perform the role of Sakka, Māra, or the Divinity.

21169.meaning_1: who has the quality of unethical physical conduct; who physically misbehaves
21169.meaning_lit: endowed with bad conduct of body
21169.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
The term describes someone who is characterised by or possesses unethical bodily actions. In the contextual sentence, it refers to the subject (aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ kāyaduccaritasamaṅgī) who is defined by their bad physical conduct.
21169.sutta_1: ‘aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ kāyaduccaritasamaṅgī taṃnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
21169.example_1: They understand: ‘It’s impossible that someone who has engaged in bad conduct of body, speech, and mind, could for that reason alone, when their body breaks up, after death, be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

30227.grammar: ind, adv, comp, abl sg of taṃnidāna
30227.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
This word is an adverbial use of the ablative singular of the compound adjective "taṃnidāna", meaning "having that as its source". In the contextual sentence, "taṃ" refers to "kāyaduccarita" (bad conduct of body), so "taṃnidānā" means "on account of that bad conduct".
30227.sutta_1: ‘aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ kāyaduccaritasamaṅgī taṃnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
30227.example_1: They understand: ‘It’s impossible that someone who has engaged in bad conduct of body, speech, and mind, could for that reason alone, when their body breaks up, after death, be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

65620.meaning_1: who has the quality of unethical speech; who verbally misbehaves
65620.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
The compound is a Tatiyā Tatpuruṣa, meaning "endowed with (vacīduccarita)". The `ī` ending indicates derivation from an `in`-stem (`samaṅgin`). In context, it refers to a person characterized by unethical speech.

51250.meaning_1: who has the quality of unethical thought; who mentally misbehaves
51250.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
In the contextual sentence, "manoduccaritasamaṅgī" refers to an individual who is characterized by or possesses unethical mental conduct, specifically in the context of leading to an undesirable rebirth. The compound functions as a descriptive adjective for such a person.
51250.sutta_1: yaṃ manoduccaritasamaṅgī taṃnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;

21237.meaning_1: who has the quality of ethical physical conduct; who has virtuous bodily behaviour
21237.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
In the contextual sentence, this adjective describes a person (implied subject) who is "endowed with good conduct of body". The compound `samaṅgī` (from `samaṅga`) typically takes an instrumental case for the object one is endowed with, hence `kāyasucaritena` in the compound construction.
21237.sutta_1: ‘aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ kāyasucaritasamaṅgī taṃnidānā tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjeyya, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti pajānāti;
21237.example_1: They understand: ‘It’s impossible that someone who has engaged in good conduct of body, speech, and mind could, for that reason alone, when their body breaks up, after death, be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

48144.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
This is a Bahubbīhi compound, meaning "that which has many elements". The contextual sentence names the "dhammapariyāya" (exposition of the teaching) as "The Many Elements", indicating that the discourse *possesses* many elements, which is characteristic of a Bahubbīhi compound.
48144.sutta_1: “tasmātiha tvaṃ, ānanda, imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ ‘bahudhātuko’tipi naṃ dhārehi, ‘catuparivaṭṭo’tipi naṃ dhārehi, ‘dhammādāso’tipi naṃ dhārehi, ‘amatadundubhī’tipi naṃ dhārehi, ‘anuttaro saṅgāmavijayo’tipi naṃ dhārehī”ti.
48144.example_1: “Well then, Ānanda, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Many Elements’, or else ‘The Four Rounds’, or else ‘The Mirror of the Teaching’, or else ‘The Drum of Freedom From Death’, or else ‘The Supreme Victory in Battle’.”

25982.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
In the contextual sentence, "catuparivaṭṭo" functions as an epithet or a name for the exposition of the teaching (dhammapariyāya), specifically meaning "The Four Rounds". These "four rounds" refer to the four aspects or turns of the teaching, often related to the Four Noble Truths or the process of dependent origination.
25982.sutta_1: “tasmātiha tvaṃ, ānanda, imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ ‘bahudhātuko’tipi naṃ dhārehi, ‘catuparivaṭṭo’tipi naṃ dhārehi, ‘dhammādāso’tipi naṃ dhārehi, ‘amatadundubhī’tipi naṃ dhārehi, ‘anuttaro saṅgāmavijayo’tipi naṃ dhārehī”ti.
25982.example_1: “Well then, Ānanda, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Many Elements’, or else ‘The Four Rounds’, or else ‘The Mirror of the Teaching’, or else ‘The Drum of Freedom From Death’, or else ‘The Supreme Victory in Battle’.”

13859.meaning_1: The Discourse on Isigili; The Isigili Sutta
13859.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
This entry refers to the 116th discourse of the Majjhima Nikāya, titled 'Isigili Sutta'. 'Isigili' is the name of a mountain near Rājagaha, which translates to 'Seers' Mountain' or 'where seers swallow'. The sutta recounts how the mountain got its name because many Paccekabuddhas (solitary Buddhas) passed away there, and their bodies were 'swallowed' by the mountain, making them invisible.

39568.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
This compound, though singular in its lemma_2 form (paccekabuddhasataṃ), refers to a collection of multiple individuals, specifically "a hundred Independent Buddhas". The contextual sentence "pañca paccekabuddhasatāni" shows that this compound can be pluralized (paccekabuddhasatāni), meaning "five hundreds of Independent Buddhas". The construction "paccekabuddhā + sata" reflects the plural nature of the counted entities combined with the singular collective "hundred".
39568.sutta_1: bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, pañca paccekabuddhasatāni imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsino ahesuṃ.
39568.example_1: Once upon a time, five hundred Independent Buddhas dwelt for a long time on this Isigili.

8954.sutta_1: “ariṭṭho nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi;
8954.example_1: “The independent Buddhas who dwelt for a long time on this Isigili were named Ariṭṭha,

29225.comment:

Tagarasikhī is listed as one of the paccekabuddhas who resided on Isigili mountain, whose names are preserved in the suttas. The literal meaning "jasmine crest" indicates a Bahubbīhi compound, meaning "one whose crest is like jasmine" or "one possessing a jasmine-like crest/flame," likely referring to a distinguishing feature or quality of the individual.
29225.sutta_1: tagarasikhī nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi;

29226.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
29226.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
This entry refers to one of the Paccekabuddhas mentioned in the Isigili Sutta (MN116). The name is a compound literally meaning "one having a jasmine crest" or "possessing a jasmine-like crest". The spelling "taggarasikhī" is used in the contextual sentence, while a related entry shows "tagarasikhī".
29226.example_1: 134. ariṭṭho nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho [paccekabuddho] imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi, upariṭṭho nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi, tagarasikhī [taggarasikhī] nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi, yasassī nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi, sudassano nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi, piyadassī nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi, gandhāro nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi, piṇḍolo nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi, upāsabho nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi, nīto nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi, tatho nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi, sutavā nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi, bhāvitatto nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi.

63875.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
63875.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
The word "Sudassana" is here used as a proper noun, referring to a specific Paccekabuddha. Its literal meaning "seeing clearly" (from su- "well, good, clearly" and dassana "seeing") reflects an auspicious or descriptive quality for such a figure.
63875.sutta_1: sudassano nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi;

16427.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
16427.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
The entry is for a proper name, Upāsabha, identified in the contextual sentence as a Paccekasambuddha (privately awakened Buddha). The name is formed by the prefix "upa" and the noun "usabha", which can mean "stud bull" or "foremost one". Although a literal meaning "near the foremost" could be inferred from its components, as a proper name, its primary meaning is the name itself. The Sanskrit equivalent is derived from the common Sanskrit root for usabha (ṛṣabha) combined with upa.
16427.sutta_1: upāsabho nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi;

38563.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
38563.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
The word 'nīta' is typically a past participle meaning 'led'. In this specific entry, it functions as a masculine proper noun, referring to the name of a Paccekabuddha (privately awakened Buddha). The contextual sentence 'Nīta, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho...' clearly illustrates this usage as a personal name.
38563.sutta_1: nīto nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi;

This confirms the meaning of `tatha` as the proper name of a Paccekabuddha. The nominative singular form `tatho` is correctly reflected in `lemma_2`.
29647.sutta_1: tatho nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi,

49837.sutta_1: bhāvitatto nāma, bhikkhave, paccekasambuddho imasmiṃ isigilismiṃ pabbate ciranivāsī ahosi.

57791.comment:

In the contextual sentence, 'sattasārā' (plural) refers to 'saintly beings', implying individuals who have realized the essence of spiritual life or who are themselves the core of such realization. The compound 'kammadhāraya' signifies that the being (satta) is qualified as being of essence (sāra), or is the essence itself.

paccekamevajjhagamaṃsu bodhiṃ [paccekamevajjhagamuṃ subodhiṃ],
tesaṃ visallāna naruttamānaṃ,
nāmāni me kittayato suṇātha.

69186.grammar: adj, masc gen pl of visalla, irreg

69186.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
The word "visallāna" is the genitive plural form of the adjective "visalla". It refers to "those who have removed the arrow" or "those who are free from the barb (of suffering/desire)". In the contextual sentence "tesaṃ visallāna naruttamānaṃ", it describes "naruttamānaṃ" (supreme men) as being "free from the barb".

21704.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
In the contextual sentence "nāmāni me kittayato suṇātha", kittayato (genitive of kittayanta) means "praising/glorifying" and refers to "me" (me). The sentence translates to "Hear me, who is praising the names." The provided English translation in the prompt does not correspond to the Pāḷi sentence.

64454.comment:

Guttijita is a proper name, specifically of a Paccekabuddha (privately awakened Buddha). 44789.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
44789.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
This entry for "passi 2" refers to the proper name of a Paccekabuddha, distinguishing it from the aorist verb form "passi" (he saw), which is a homograph. The contextual sentence "passi jahi upadhidukkhamūlaṃ" clearly uses "Passi" as the subject of the verb "jahi" (abandoned), confirming its noun status. 15687.meaning_1: attachment which is the root of suffering
15687.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
The compound combines "upadhi" (attachment, acquisition, appropriation), "dukkha" (suffering), and "mūla" (root). "Dukkhamūla" itself is a chaṭṭhī tappurisa compound meaning "root of suffering". The larger compound "upadhidukkhamūla" is a kammadhāraya, where "upadhi" is identified as the "root of suffering". This interpretation is consistent with the contextual sentence, "Passin gave up attachment, suffering’s root", which equates "attachment" with "suffering’s root".
15687.example_1: Passin gave up attachment, suffering’s root,

6315.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
6315.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
The word aparājito functions as a proper noun, referring to Aparājita, a Paccekabuddha. The contextual sentence highlights his role as the one who "defeated Māra’s power", which aligns with his name meaning "undefeated".

44847.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
44847.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
The contextual sentence uses 'pavattā' as an epithet for the Buddha, translated as 'proclaimer', which aligns with its literal meaning and the primary meaning of 'pavattar 1'. This entry, 'pavattar 2', specifically refers to its use as a proper name for a Paccekabuddha.
44847.sutta_1: so hāvuso, bhagavā jānaṃ jānāti, passaṃ passati, cakkhubhūto ñāṇabhūto dhammabhūto brahmabhūto, vattā pavattā, atthassa ninnetā, amatassa dātā, dhammassāmī tathāgato.
44847.example_1: For he is the Buddha, the one who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the manifestation of principle, he is the manifestation of divinity. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of freedom from death, the lord of truth, the Realized One.

61037.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
61037.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
The name Sarabhaṅga, literally "reed breaker", refers to a Paccekabuddha. In the contextual sentence from MN 116, "Sarabhaṅga" is listed among other Paccekabuddhas or great figures. The compound construction has been corrected to reflect a dutiyā tappurisa, where "sara" (reed) is the object of "bhaṅga" (breaking).

56138.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
56138.comment:

In the contextual sentence, "Lomahaṁsa" is used as a proper name, confirming its meaning as a name of a Paccekabuddha. This is distinct from "lomahaṃsa 1", which refers to the physical sensation of goosebumps.

14275.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha

9730.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha

The contextual sentence uses "asita" as an epithet meaning "the Dark" for the seer Devala, which aligns with a meaning found in "asita 2.2". This specific entry (asita 2.3), however, refers to "Asita" as a proper name for a privately awakened Buddha, consistent with its "family_set" field.
9730.sutta_1: assosi kho, assalāyana, asito devalo isi:
9730.example_1: The seer Devala the Dark heard about this.

4054.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha

51272.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha

This entry refers to Manomaya, a Paccekabuddha mentioned in the provided text, alongside Bandhumā.
51272.example_1: Manomaya, and Bandhumā the cutter of conceit,

52266.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
52266.comment:

This entry refers to a specific Paccekabuddha named 'Mānacchida', as indicated by '2' in the lemma and its inclusion in the 'names of paccekabuddhas' set. The contextual sentence from mn116:6.15 shows it functioning as a proper noun alongside 'Manomaya' and 'Bandhumā', where its literal meaning 'cutter of conceit' serves as an epithet.
52266.example_1: Manomaya, and Bandhumā the cutter of conceit,

47959.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
47959.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
The word `Bandhumā` in the contextual sentence is the nominative singular form of `bandhumant`. It refers to a Paccekabuddha (privately awakened Buddha). The literal meaning "having bonds" connects to the root `√bandh` (to bind, tie) and the noun `bandhu` (kinsman; bond/tie). In the context of a Buddha, this name could symbolically refer to one who has broken all worldly bonds, or possesses qualities related to fundamental connections.
47959.example_1: Manomaya, and Bandhumā the cutter of conceit,

68666.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
68666.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
In the contextual sentence "tadādhimutto vimalo ca ketumā", `vimalo` is used as a proper noun, appearing in a list of names alongside `Adhimutto` and `Ketumā`. This usage directly supports its meaning as "name of a privately awakened Buddha" (Paccekabuddha).
68666.example_1: then Adhimutta, and Ketumā the immaculate.

22825.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
22825.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
In the contextual sentence, "Ketumā" is the nominative singular masculine form of "ketumant," referring to the Paccekabuddha Ketumā, who is described as "immaculate" (vimalo). The suffix "-mant" indicates possession or quality, making the literal meaning "having banner quality" or "possessed of a banner." This entry is specifically for the Paccekabuddha name, distinct from other uses of "ketumant".
22825.example_1: then Adhimutta, and Ketumā the immaculate.

52170.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
52170.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
The contextual sentence from mn116:6.17 demonstrates "Mātaṅga" functioning as a proper noun, listed among other names, which aligns with its meaning as the name of a Paccekabuddha.

1004.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
1004.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
In the contextual sentence, "Accuta" is used as a proper noun, the name of an individual, consistent with its meaning as a name of a Paccekabuddha. It appears as part of a list of names.

1005.meaning_1: name of two privately awakened Buddhas; Accutagāma and Byāmaka
1005.comment:

64279.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
64279.comment:

In the contextual sentence 'Sumaṅgalo dabbilo supatiṭṭhito', 'Sumaṅgalo' is used as a proper name, confirming its meaning as a name rather than an adjective.

64070.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
64070.comment:

9600.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
9600.comment:

In the contextual sentence, 'asayho' is used as a proper noun, specifically a name, aligning with its definition as 'name of a privately awakened Buddha'.

23952.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
23952.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
In the contextual sentence, "Khemābhirata" functions as a proper noun, a name of one of the Paccekabuddhas being listed. The literal meaning "delighting in safety" aptly describes the state of a Paccekabuddha who has attained Nibbāna, which is the ultimate safety or security.

65392.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
65392.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20
In the contextual sentence, "Sorata" functions as a proper noun, specifically identified as the name of a Paccekabuddha, alongside other names like Asayha and Khemābhirata.

33773.meaning_1: name of a privately awakened Buddha
33773.comment:
